node.title: Stock slump steepens as traders wait for U.S. wage inflation data.
node.alt: New York Stock Exchange in Manhattan.Â The S&P 500 has zigzagged between gains and losses throughout the week.
node.description: By Coral Murphy Marcos and Eshe Nelson
node.content: ["Stocks dropped on Friday, extending a volatile week, after data showed that Europe\u2019s largest economy contracted more than expected late last year, and traders waited for new data on wage inflation in the United States.", "The Stoxx Europe 600 fell 2 percent. Germany\u2019s economy shrank 0.7 percent in the fourth quarter of last year, hampered by a rise in Omicron cases and supply chain bottlenecks.", "In the United States, futures indicated that the S&P 500 would open down by nearly 1 percent when trading begins. It is already on the verge of a correction, which is Wall Street\u2019s term for a drop of 10 percent from its recent high. It\u2019s a marker of investors\u2019 swiftly changing attitude about the prospects for the economy.", "The S&P 500 has zigzagged between gains and losses throughout the week \u2014 with moves of as much as 4 percent during a single day \u2014 as investors try to assess how much the Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates to combat inflation.", "Wall Street is virtually certain that the central bank will start its rate increases in March, but the question now is by how much, and how often will it do so.", "Investors will soon get an important new data point to focus on when the Labor Department releases the Employment Cost Index on Friday. It\u2019s a measure of wages and salaries that is reported every three months, and can serve as an indicator of whether wage growth is keeping up with inflation.", "Economists are expecting the index to have risen 1.2 percent in the three months through December. That would be a slight slowdown from the 1.3 percent increase reported for the previous quarter, the fastest pace in records going back to 1996.", "But a surprise jump would be problematic for Wall Street, raising bets that the Fed will take bigger steps to try and choke off inflation.", "\u201cIf you have another record increase in the E.C.I., that would be enough of an indicator that would spark the debate that the Fed needs to be extra aggressive to get more bang for your buck in fighting inflation,\u201d said Edward Moya, a market analyst at OANDA, a foreign currency exchange and brokerage firm.", "January was already shaping up to be a dismal month for stock investors, who were initially spooked by a big jump in government bond yields \u2014 a benchmark of borrowing costs across the economy \u2014 and then disappointed by corporate earnings reports or forecasts for the year ahead from companies as varied as Goldman Sachs and Netflix.", "On Thursday, for example, shares of the electric vehicle maker Tesla slid more than 11 percent, weighing on the broader S&P 500, after the company said that supply chain problems would put a constraint on production in the coming year.", "By the close of trading on Thursday, the S&P 500 was down 9.8 percent from its Jan 3. high, meaning that even a small decline on Friday would leave the market in a correction.", "\u201cA correction signifies that the economy has really lost momentum,\u201d said Mr. Moya. \u201cWe\u2019re seeing fear in the market because there\u2019s concerns that the economy is going to be struggling going forward.\u201d"]
